if you have any of these risk factors ,your risk may be higher than what is shown in the tool
Do you have any of these health conditions ?
The DASS-21 should not be used to replace a face to face clinical interview. If you are experiencing significant emotional difficulties you should contact your doctor.

The Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale - 21 Items (DASS-21) is a set of three self-report scales designed to measure the emotional states of depression, anxiety and stress. Each of the three DASS-21 scales contains 7 items, divided into subscales with similar content.

The Hypertension calculator gives you an overall idea of the health and a general indication of how lifestyle-related factors may affect your Blood Pressure. The risk has been calculated based on the parameters for your age group, gender.
The Heart Age and Risk gives you a overall idea of the health of your heart and general indication of how lifestyle related factors may affect your heart health.
Its time to make some changes !
You have following Non Modifiable Risk
You have mild nomophobia. You get a little antsy when you forget your phone at home for a day or get stuck somewhere without WiFi, but the anxiety isn\'t too overwhelming.

You have moderate nomophobia. You\'re pretty attached to your device. You often check for updates while you\'re walking down the street or talking to a friend, and you often feel anxious when you\'re disconnected. You are just on the edge of becoming addicted. However, it is good that you do not let your Smartphone come in the way. Sometimes, you avoid your phone and feel bad for it, but the rest part of being with family, children, etc, makes you happy. So, you just need to beware!.

You have severe nomophobia. You can barely go for 60 seconds without checking your phone. It\'s the first thing you check in the morning and the last at night, and dominates most of your activities in-between. You are definitely suffering from Nomophobia, and God help others if you forget your phone at home or lose it! You are so addicted to your phone that you sometimes wonder what if you could stick your phone to the hand!.
Are you under Medication for High Blood Pressure?
Have either of your parents or any of your siblings been diagnosed with Diabetes?
Have you ever been found to have High Blood Sugar(during health checkup/an illness/pregnency)?
Are you currently taking medication for high Blood Pressure?
Do you currently smoke cigarettes or any other tobacco products on a daily basis?
Do you eat fruits and vegetables 2 to 3 times a day?
On an average,do you exercise for more than 3 hours a week?
I felt that life was meaningless.
I felt I wasn’t worth much as a person.
I was unable to become enthusiastic about anything.
I felt that I had nothing to look forward to
I found it difficult to work up the initiative to do things
I couldn’t seem to experience any positive feeling at all
I felt scared without any good reason
I was aware of the action of my heart in the absence of physical exertion\n" (e.g. Sense of a heart rate increase, heart missing a beat)
I felt I was close to panic
I was worried about situations in which I might panic and make a fool of myself
I experienced trembling in the hands
I experienced breathing difficulty\n" (eg, excessively rapid breathing, breathlessness in the absence of physical exertion)
I was aware of dryness of my mouth
I felt that I was rather touchy
I was intolerant of anything that kept me from getting on with what I was doing
I found it difficult to relax
I felt that I was using a lot of nervous energy
I tended to over-react to situations
I found it hard to wind down
Do you often think that your smartphone is ringing/vibrating when it is not?
When your phone rings buzzes , do you feel an intense urge to check ?
Do you look at your phone after you get up in the morning or before going to bed?
Do you sleep with your smartphone on or under your pillow or next to your bed?
Do you text, e-mail/surfed the web while waiting at the traffic signal?
Do you constantly check your phone if you did not have a data signal or Wi-Fi?
Do you feel a great deal of anxiety if your phone not working/you accidentally left it?
Do you find yourself Always passing time in searching on google/E-commerce sites?
Do you spend more time texting, tweeting/emailing than talking to real-time people?
When you eat meals, is your cell phone always part of the table place setting?
Do you feel lonely if your smartphone doesn\'t ring for several hours?
Over use of your cell phone or smartphone can result in a number of different physical problems that may cause permanent damage or be difficult to treat, including:
Psychological Effects of Cell Phone Addiction
Eyes begin to burn and itch.
Digital Eye Strain can cause headaches.
The pain and discomfort associated with viewing a digital screen for over 2 hours.
Also known as "text neck," which refers to neck pain resulting from looking down at cell phone or tablet for too long.
1 in 6 cell phones has fecal matter on it.
E. coli bacteria, which can cause fever, vomiting, and diarrhea, is found on many phones.
Phones have been found to be contaminated with MRSA.
Life-threatening infections in bones, joints, surgical wounds, bloodstream, heart valves, and lungs.
Many people believe that they can multitask and use their phones while driving, but this causes significant impairment and puts the driver and others on the road in danger.
Research has revealed that texting and driving can be just as dangerous as drinking and driving.
Preliminary studies have revealed that cell phone radiation may decrease sperm count, sperm motility and viability.
Cell phone addiction has been linked to an increase in sleep disorders and fatigue in users.
Using your cell phone before bed increases the likelihood of insomnia.
Bright light may decrease sleep quality.
Smartphone use could increase amount of time it takes to fall asleep.
Light emitted from the cell phone may activate the brain.
Offline relationships may suffer as a result of neglect in favor of excessive cell phone and social media use.
Research has found that college students who use their cell phones the most are more likely to feel anxious during downtime.
